awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Impact of Mechanical Constraints on the Dendrite Formation in Lithium Metal Anodes
awd_abstract_narration:
Lithium metal is one of the most appealing anode materials for lithium-ion batteries due to its high specific capacity and its low density and negative electrochemical potential. Utilizing lithium metal in lithium/air or lithium/sulfur batteries can achieve a theoretical specific energy several times higher than in existing lithium-ion batteries, which could boost technology innovations of lithium-ion batteries based applications such as portable electronics, electric vehicles, and energy storage systems. However, dendritic lithium growth during charge/discharge cycles poses a major safety challenge to cells made with lithium metal anodes. In this project, dendritic lithium growth is suppressed by inserting an extra stiff layer in lithium-ion batteries acting as a mechanical constraint. The project will fundamentally improve the understanding of the relationship between mechanical deformation and lithium dendrite growth. New generation workforce will be trained in the use of state-of-art computational tools to conduct multidisciplinary research at the interface between computational mechanics and electrochemistry. New course contents on energy storage material properties and modeling aspects will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses and hands-on activities will be created to teach high school students various energy-related topics.

The research goal of this project is to fundamentally understand the role of mechanical deformation on lithium dendrite formation using a new computational modeling framework. This framework includes a staggered optimization scheme to account for an evolving lithium anode geometry and various multiphysics effects during lithium dendrite formation under mechanical constraints. Resulting phase diagrams will provide experimentalists new insights on the dendrite behavior to tailor material properties and cell design to suppress dendrites. The research will untangle the complex coupling between electrochemical, thermal, and mechanical behaviors at dendrite interfaces. It will answer many fundamental questions such as whether or not dendrites will penetrate the separator by passing through its pores or by piercing it, how mechanics changes the electrochemical properties at the vicinity of dendrites, or how mechanics is changing dendrite morphologies. Ultimately, this work will provide feedback to experimentalists to engineer interface designs and structural designs for better and safer lithium metal anodes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand electro-chemo-thermo-mechanical systems and their resistance to failure. Initially, a sophisticated computational framework that integrates electrochemical, thermal, and mechanical factors within a three-dimensional model tailored for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) was developed. The interplay of thermal and mechanical influences is pivotal in shaping the electrochemical dynamics of LIBs. Variances in temperature distribution and mechanical stress can lead to disparate electrochemical conditions, causing localized aging and consequent reductions in cell longevity. To enhance the precision of computational battery design optimization, it is imperative to account for these interrelated phenomena comprehensively within a simulation model encompassing the entire battery cell. Thus, this project introduces an integrated electro-chemo-thermo-mechanical framework specifically designed for simulating LIBs within a three-dimensional space. This innovative framework combines a recently developed one-dimensional electrochemical model—incorporating mechanical deformation and localized lithiation effects on charge transport properties—with a three-dimensional thermomechanical model. Such an approach enables accurate and efficient analysis of three-dimensional cells with realistic geometries, enabling precise resolution of spatial variations in key parameters. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework, simulations on two commercial cells were conducted, showcasing their performance and potential for advancing battery simulation methodologies. Subsequently, the influence of mechanical constraints was investigated by introducing a refined electrochemical model to address the ramifications of lithium intercalation and external pressure on battery performance. In the realm of battery cells, both electrode/separator porosity and the transport distance of charged particles can undergo alterations due to mechanical stresses induced by lithium intercalation-induced expansion and contraction of active particles or externally applied mechanical forces. To accurately capture the intricate interplay between mechanical deformation and the electrochemical behavior of the cell, Newman's DualFoil model was expanded. This extension incorporates variable, non-uniform porosities in both electrodes and the separator, dynamically adjusting them based on the battery cell's electrochemical and mechanical conditions. Additionally, finite deformation theory from continuum mechanics was employed to refine the electrochemical transport equations, accommodating changes in the transport distance of charged species. To validate our approach, a parameterized commercial cell was subject to a coupled electro-chemo-mechanical model. The simulations not only confirmed the preservation of mass but also highlighted the substantial influence of mechanical effects on the electrochemical response of the cell, particularly under high charge/discharge rates. Following, a deeper insight into how thermal and mechanical factors impact lithium plating within lithium-ion batteries was attained. Lithium plating poses a significant challenge to cell durability, leading to diminished cyclable lithium and reduced cell capacity over time. Thermal and mechanical stresses can exert notable influence on cell behavior, affecting the driving forces behind lithium plating as described by the Arrhenius equation and the Bruggeman relation, respectively. To comprehensively investigate these effects, both a 1D and a 3D model were employed to scrutinize the thermal and mechanical influences on lithium plating in lithium-ion batteries boasting high areal capacities. In tandem with physics-based models, this project introduced a novel physics-informed deep learning model named SenseNet, aimed at perceptively gauging the mechanical deformation of batteries featuring thick geometries. SenseNet comprises two integral components: the neural network and the physics module. Within the neural network, the input consists of coordinates of sampled material points, while the output yields corresponding predicted displacements. SenseNet remains agnostic regarding the architecture of the neural network, offering flexibility in its design. Leveraging this flexibility, a straightforward, fully connected feed-forward neural network was developed for this endeavor. To overcome the necessity for vast amounts of labeled data, a physics module was integrated into the model architecture. Lastly, we have developed a suite of advanced phase-field fracture methodologies tailored for quasi-brittle and ductile material systems within this project, enriching our understanding of the impact of dendrite formation in electro-chemo-thermo-mechanical systems.


In addition to generating scientific impact through a gained understanding of new physics-based and data driven approaches for electro-chemo-thermo-mechanical systems, a robust education plan was tightly integrated into the project research in a variety of creative ways to impact students from high school through graduate school, and a high school teacher from a school with a large number of students typically underrepresented in higher eduction.


Last Modified: 04/03/2024
Modified by: Christian Linder
